questiontext.text:

  6. What is the probability a random card is a rug? {3:NUMERICAL:=0.272:0.01}

questiontext.text:
A spinner has the probability distribution shown below.

xx Pr(x)\text{Pr}(x)
4 0.2
9 0.3
13 0.1
24 0.25
28 0.15
  1. What is the probability of spinning 9? In other words, what is Pr(X=9)\text{Pr}(X=9)? {3:NUMERICAL:=0.3:0.01}
  2. What is the probability of spinning 9 or 24? In other words, what is Pr(X=9 or X=24)\text{Pr}(X=9 ~\text{ or }~ X=24)? {3:NUMERICAL:=0.55:0.01}
  3. If spinning twice, what is the probability of first spinning 9 and then spinning 24? In other words, what is Pr(X1=9 and X2=24)\text{Pr}(X_1=9 ~\text{ and }~ X_2=24)? {3:NUMERICAL:=0.075:0.01}
  4. What is the probability of spinning at least 13? In other words, what is Pr(X≥13)\text{Pr}(X\ge 13)? {3:NUMERICAL:=0.5:0.01}
  5. Determine the mean of the probability distribution by using μ=∑x⋅Pr(x)\mu = \sum x\cdot \text{Pr}(x). {4:NUMERICAL:=15:0.01}
  6. Determine the standard deviation of the probability distribution by using σ=∑(x−μ)2⋅Pr(x)\sigma = \sqrt{\sum (x-\mu)^2 \cdot \text{Pr}(x)}. {4:NUMERICAL:=9:0.01}

generalfeedback.text:

xx Pr(x)\text{Pr}(x) x⋅Pr(x)x\cdot\text{Pr}(x) x−μx-\mu (x−μ)2(x-\mu)^2 (x−μ)2⋅Pr(x)(x-\mu)^2 \cdot \text{Pr}(x)
4 0.2 0.8 -11 121 24.2
9 0.3 2.7 -6 36 10.8
13 0.1 1.3 -2 4 0.4
24 0.25 6 9 81 20.25
28 0.15 4.2 13 169 25.35
========= ========= ========= ========= ========= =========
∑x⋅Pr(x)=15\sum x \cdot \text{Pr}(x) = 15 σ2=81\sigma^2 = 81
μ=15\mu = 15 σ=9\sigma = 9
  1. 0.3
  2. 0.3+0.250.3 + 0.25 = 0.55
  3. 0.3×0.250.3 \times 0.25 = 0.075
  4. 0.5
  5. μ=15\mu = 15
  6. σ=9\sigma = 9

questiontext.text: A team has 15 players. The coach needs to pick 5 starters. How many possibilities exist?

generalfeedback.text:
This scenario describes a combinations problem (order does not matter). We are considering the subsets of size 5 from a set of size 15.

nCr=n!(n−r)!⋅r!n=15r=515C5=15!(15−5)!⋅5!=15!10!⋅5!=15⋅14⋅13⋅12⋅115⋅4⋅3⋅2⋅1=3003\begin{aligned} {_nC_r} &= \frac{n!}{(n-r)! \cdot r!} \\\\ n &= 15 \\\\ r &= 5 \\\\ {_{15}C_{5}} &= \frac{15!}{(15-5)!\cdot 5! } \\\\ &= \frac{15!}{10! \cdot 5!} \\\\ &= \frac{ 15\cdot14\cdot13\cdot12\cdot11}{ 5\cdot4\cdot3\cdot2\cdot1} \\\\ &= 3003 \end{aligned}

questiontext.text: From a set with 14 elements, how many subsets with 3 elements are possible? (A set is an orderless, nonrepeating collection of elements.)

generalfeedback.text:
This scenario describes a combinations problem (order does not matter). We are considering the subsets of size 3 from a set of size 14.

nCr=n!(n−r)!⋅r!n=14r=314C3=14!(14−3)!⋅3!=14!11!⋅3!=14⋅13⋅123⋅2⋅1=364\begin{aligned} {_nC_r} &= \frac{n!}{(n-r)! \cdot r!} \\\\ n &= 14 \\\\ r &= 3 \\\\ {_{14}C_{3}} &= \frac{14!}{(14-3)!\cdot 3! } \\\\ &= \frac{14!}{11! \cdot 3!} \\\\ &= \frac{ 14\cdot13\cdot12}{ 3\cdot2\cdot1} \\\\ &= 364 \end{aligned}

questiontext.text: A deck has 25 different cards. From that deck, 4 cards are dealt into a player’s hand. How many different hands are possible?

This scenario describes a combinations problem (order does not matter). We are considering the subsets of size 4 from a set of size 25.

nCr=n!(n−r)!⋅r!n=25r=425C4=25!(25−4)!⋅4!=25!21!⋅4!=25⋅24⋅23⋅224⋅3⋅2⋅1=12650\begin{aligned} {_nC_r} &= \frac{n!}{(n-r)! \cdot r!} \\\\ n &= 25 \\\\ r &= 4 \\\\ {_{25}C_{4}} &= \frac{25!}{(25-4)!\cdot 4! } \\\\ &= \frac{25!}{21! \cdot 4!} \\\\ &= \frac{ 25\cdot24\cdot23\cdot22}{ 4\cdot3\cdot2\cdot1} \\\\ &= 12650 \end{aligned}

generalfeedback.text:
This scenario describes a permutations problem (order matters). We are considering the nonrepeating sequences of size 4 from a set of size 10.

nPr=n!(n−r)!n=10r=410P4=10!(10−4)!=10!6!=10⋅9⋅8⋅7=5040\begin{aligned} {_nP_r} &= \frac{n!}{(n-r)!} \\\\ n &= 10 \\\\ r &= 4 \\\\ {_{10}P_{4}} &= \frac{10!}{(10-4)! } \\\\ &= \frac{10!}{6!} \\\\ &= 10\cdot9\cdot8\cdot7 \\\\ &= 5040 \end{aligned}

questiontext.text: A basketball team has 10 players. The coach needs to pick players to fill 3 different positions. How many ways could the coach do this?

generalfeedback.text:
This scenario describes a permutations problem (order matters). We are considering the nonrepeating sequences of size 3 from a set of size 10.

nPr=n!(n−r)!n=10r=310P3=10!(10−3)!=10!7!=10⋅9⋅8=720\begin{aligned} {_nP_r} &= \frac{n!}{(n-r)!} \\\\ n &= 10 \\\\ r &= 3 \\\\ {_{10}P_{3}} &= \frac{10!}{(10-3)! } \\\\ &= \frac{10!}{7!} \\\\ &= 10\cdot9\cdot8 \\\\ &= 720 \end{aligned}

questiontext.text: A basketball team has 8 players. The coach needs to pick players to fill 3 different positions. How many ways could the coach do this?

generalfeedback.text:
This scenario describes a permutations problem (order matters). We are considering the nonrepeating sequences of size 3 from a set of size 8.

nPr=n!(n−r)!n=8r=38P3=8!(8−3)!=8!5!=8⋅7⋅6=336\begin{aligned} {_nP_r} &= \frac{n!}{(n-r)!} \\\\ n &= 8 \\\\ r &= 3 \\\\ {_{8}P_{3}} &= \frac{8!}{(8-3)! } \\\\ &= \frac{8!}{5!} \\\\ &= 8\cdot7\cdot6 \\\\ &= 336 \end{aligned}

questiontext.text: An event planner hosts a different activity each day. The planner still needs to schedule activities for Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday. The planner has 16 different activities available to choose from. How many schedules are possible?

generalfeedback.text:
This scenario describes a permutations problem (order matters). We are considering the nonrepeating sequences of size 4 from a set of size 16.

nPr=n!(n−r)!n=16r=416P4=16!(16−4)!=16!12!=16⋅15⋅14⋅13=43680\begin{aligned} {_nP_r} &= \frac{n!}{(n-r)!} \\\\ n &= 16 \\\\ r &= 4 \\\\ {_{16}P_{4}} &= \frac{16!}{(16-4)! } \\\\ &= \frac{16!}{12!} \\\\ &= 16\cdot15\cdot14\cdot13 \\\\ &= 43680 \end{aligned}

questiontext.text: An event planner hosts a different activity each day. The planner still needs to schedule activities for Monday and Tuesday. The planner has 24 different activities available to choose from. How many schedules are possible?

generalfeedback.text:
This scenario describes a permutations problem (order matters). We are considering the nonrepeating sequences of size 2 from a set of size 24.

nPr=n!(n−r)!n=24r=224P2=24!(24−2)!=24!22!=24⋅23=552\begin{aligned} {_nP_r} &= \frac{n!}{(n-r)!} \\\\ n &= 24 \\\\ r &= 2 \\\\ {_{24}P_{2}} &= \frac{24!}{(24-2)! } \\\\ &= \frac{24!}{22!} \\\\ &= 24\cdot23 \\\\ &= 552 \end{aligned}

questiontext.text: A human is choosing different colors for his scarf, pants, shirt, and hat. The same 13 colors are available for each item. How many color configurations are possible? (The same color can not be used twice.)

generalfeedback.text:
This scenario describes a permutations problem (order matters). We are considering the nonrepeating sequences of size 4 from a set of size 13.

nPr=n!(n−r)!n=13r=413P4=13!(13−4)!=13!9!=13⋅12⋅11⋅10=17160\begin{aligned} {_nP_r} &= \frac{n!}{(n-r)!} \\\\ n &= 13 \\\\ r &= 4 \\\\ {_{13}P_{4}} &= \frac{13!}{(13-4)! } \\\\ &= \frac{13!}{9!} \\\\ &= 13\cdot12\cdot11\cdot10 \\\\ &= 17160 \end{aligned}

questiontext.text: A human is choosing different colors for his hat, scarf, shirt, belt, and pants. The same 18 colors are available for each item. How many color configurations are possible? (The same color can not be used twice.)

generalfeedback.text:
This scenario describes a permutations problem (order matters). We are considering the nonrepeating sequences of size 5 from a set of size 18.

nPr=n!(n−r)!n=18r=518P5=18!(18−5)!=18!13!=18⋅17⋅16⋅15⋅14=1028160\begin{aligned} {_nP_r} &= \frac{n!}{(n-r)!} \\\\ n &= 18 \\\\ r &= 5 \\\\ {_{18}P_{5}} &= \frac{18!}{(18-5)! } \\\\ &= \frac{18!}{13!} \\\\ &= 18\cdot17\cdot16\cdot15\cdot14 \\\\ &= 1028160 \end{aligned}

questiontext.text:

  2. What is the probability of getting exactly 2 successes? In other words, determine Pr(X=2)\text{Pr}(X = 2). {3:NUMERICAL:=0.219415:0.01}
  3. What is the probability of getting more than 2 successes? In other words, determine Pr(X>2)\text{Pr}(X > 2). {2:NUMERICAL:=0.6633607:0.01}
  4. What is the probability of getting at least 2 successes? In other words, determine Pr(X≥2)\text{Pr}(X \ge 2). {2:NUMERICAL:=0.8827757:0.01}
  5. What is the probability of getting less than 2 successes? In other words, determine Pr(X<2)\text{Pr}(X < 2). {2:NUMERICAL:=0.1172243:0.01}
  6. What is the probability of getting at most 2 successes? In other words, determine Pr(X≤2)\text{Pr}(X \le 2). {2:NUMERICAL:=0.3366393:0.01}
  7. Determine the mean number of successes. {3:NUMERICAL:=3.12:0.01}
  8. Determine the standard deviation of successes. {3:NUMERICAL:=1.3795651:0.01}

This is a binomial distribution, so use the appropriate formulas. You may need to use P(X=x)=nCx⋅px(1−p)n−xP(X=x) ~=~ _n\text{C}_x \cdot p^x(1-p)^{n-x} up to 4 times… but you do not need to use it 99 times (which you would do to determine the entire probability distribution). You will instead need to use the compliment rule.

  1. Pr(X=4)=8C4⋅0.3940.614=0.2242208\text{Pr}(X=4) ~=~ {_{8}}C_{4}\cdot0.39^{4} 0.61^{4} ~=~ 0.2242208
  2. Pr(X=2)=8C2⋅0.3920.616=0.219415\text{Pr}(X=2) ~=~ {_{8}}C_{2}\cdot0.39^{2} 0.61^{6} ~=~ 0.219415
  3. Pr(X>2)=0.6633607\text{Pr}(X > 2) ~=~ 0.6633607
  4. Pr(X≥2)=0.8827757\text{Pr}(X \ge 2) ~=~ 0.8827757
  5. Pr(X<2)=0.1172243\text{Pr}(X < 2) ~=~ 0.1172243
  6. Pr(X≤2)=0.3366393\text{Pr}(X \le 2) ~=~ 0.3366393
  7. Because this is a binomial distribution, μ=np\mu = np, so μ=3.12\mu = 3.12
  8. Because this is a binomial distribution, σ=npq\sigma = \sqrt{npq}, so σ=1.3795651\sigma = 1.3795651

questiontext.text:
Bob has a 66% chance of winning a game. If Bob wins, he has a 41% chance of being happy. If Bob loses, he has a 22% chance of being happy.

After his game, you notice Bob is happy. What is the probability that Bob won his game? (Do not answer as a percentage; answer as a decimal.)

generalfeedback.text:
Use the definition of conditional probability. P(win given happy)=P(win and happy)P(happy)P(\text{win given happy}) = \frac{P(\text{win and happy})}{P(\text{happy})} We can first determine all the joint probabilities. P(A and B)=P(A)⋅P(B given A)P(A\text{ and }B) = P(A)\cdot P(B\text{ given } A) P(win and happy)=0.66×0.41=0.2706P(win and sad)=0.66×(1−0.41)=0.3894P(lose and happy)=(1−0.66)×0.22=0.0748P(lose and sad)=(1−0.66)×(1−0.22)=0.2652\begin{aligned} P(\text{win and happy}) &= 0.66\times0.41 = 0.2706\\ P(\text{win and sad}) &= 0.66\times(1-0.41) = 0.3894\\ P(\text{lose and happy}) &= (1-0.66)\times0.22 = 0.0748\\ P(\text{lose and sad}) &= (1-0.66)\times(1-0.22) = 0.2652\\ \end{aligned}

Notice there are two disjoint ways Bob could be happy. P(happy)=P([win and happy] OR [lose and happy])=P(win and happy)+P(lose and happy)=0.2706+0.0748=0.3454\begin{aligned} P(\text{happy}) &= P\left(\text{[win and happy] OR [lose and happy]}\right) \\ &= P(\text{win and happy}) + P(\text{lose and happy}) \\ &= 0.2706+0.0748 \\ &= 0.3454 \end{aligned} So, back to the conditional probability. P(win given happy)=0.27060.3454=0.783P(\text{win given happy}) = \frac{0.2706}{0.3454} = 0.783
